Description: Mould-made scarab in glazed composition; back marked with single lines for clypeus, prothorax and elytra, and small triangles marking winglets on either side behind the prothorax line; humeral callosities indicated by v-shaped nicks; at side, legs quite well-modelled with undercut triangle; underside decorated with representation of a lion walking to right with head looking forward and tail held high, sun-disc above its back and an unidentified element (hieroglyphic sign?) in front of animal; motif stamped rather than incised, encircled by groove near edge; longitudinally pierced; yellow glaze badly preserved; fine pale yellow core, back quite rubbed.
Curator's comments: Scarabs with a lion motif depicted on the base belong to a standard group produced at the 'Scarab Factory' (on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming). Petrie illustrated a number of different versions (Petrie 1886, pl. 37, 34-45). This scarab belongs to a type which was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 93, 95-96, type XXVIII A, subtype A6-39, see especially A7 for this piece). Gorton, A. F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W. M. F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, 'Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site', in R. Thomas (ed.), forthcoming, Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 37)
Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 94 and 96, Type XXVIII A7)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OC.001) (phase 3)
Condition: Rather fair, though back bit eroded
